Issues.Title: fix(compiler): incorrectly inferring namespace for HTML nodes inside SVG
Issues.Body:
The HTML parser gets an element's namespace either from the tag name (e.g. `<svg:rect>`) or from its parent element `<svg><rect></svg>`) which breaks down when an element is inside of an SVG `foreignElement`, because foreign elements allow nodes from a different namespace to be inserted into an SVG.

These changes special-case `foreignElement` as a node that descendants shouldn't inherit their namespace from.

Fixes #37218.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(compiler): incorrectly inferring namespace for HTML nodes inside SVG" (#38477)

Issues.Title: fix(zone.js): disable wrap uncaught promise rejection should handle primitive value
Issues.Body:
Close #38334

zone.js provides a flag DISABLE_WRAPPING_UNCAUGHT_PROMISE_REJECTION to let zone.js
throw the original error instead of wrap it when uncaught promise rejection found.
But the rejection value could be anything includes primitive value such as number.
In that case, we should not attach any additional properties to the value.

# Mistake in [Hierarchical Injection] "@Host and viewProviders" section's logical tree representation"

### Description

Following the hierarchical injection tree representation logic, the Injection of AnimalService need to be fixed. 

Below is the logical tree representation in "Hierarchical Injection" - "`@Host` and viewProviders" section:
![screenshot-1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11903242/90287100-2c908580-de45-11ea-80d3-090ffbcd87e3.png)
There are 2 mistakes: 
(1) The root component's viewProviders shouldn't have `@SkipSelf` and `@Host`. These two modifiers aren't necessary and I guess they should only belong to the child component in this case. Although strickly speaking, in this case, the root component's injector will not change the result in child component. However, the real injector's value in root component should be 'null', instead of ü¶î . I think 'changing the value to null' or 'removing the `@SkipSelf` and `@Host` modifiers' both works.

(2) The child component's injector value should be ü¶î, instead of üê∂. I think this also fits the conclusion of the document and the real test result.

So below is the expecting fix of current representation:
![screenshot-3](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11903242/90288223-6c586c80-de47-11ea-8e05-34e5e5379861.png)

I think logical tree representation is a good idea to represent the details of the injection process. I met the issue to understand the value in this one and I tested the value following the project structure to verify, so I guess this is an editing error.

If I have some misunderstandings for the document, looking forward to your correction. 

Thank you for your work and the constantly update!

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction

https://angular.io/guide/hierarchical-dependency-injection#host-and-viewproviders

## üì∑Screenshot
![screenshot-1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11903242/90287100-2c908580-de45-11ea-80d3-090ffbcd87e3.png)

![screenshot-3](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11903242/90288223-6c586c80-de47-11ea-8e05-34e5e5379861.png)

![screenshot-2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11903242/90287522-07e8dd80-de46-11ea-8aaf-7b4338e28cb0.png)

Issues.Title: fix(common): Allow scrolling when browser supports scrollTo
Issues.Body:
This commit fixes a regression from "fix(common): ensure
scrollRestoration is writable (#30630)" that caused scrolling to not
happen at all in browsers that do not support scroll restoration. The
issue was that `supportScrollRestoration` was updated to return `false`
if a browser did not have a writable `scrollRestoration`. However, the
previous behavior was that the function would return `true` if
`window.scrollTo` was defined. Every scrolling function in the
`ViewportScroller` used `supportScrollRestoration` and, with the update
in bb88c9fa3daac80086efbda951d81c159e3840f4, no scrolling would be
performed if a browser did not have writable `scrollRestoration` but
_did_ have `window.scrollTo`.

Note, that this failure was detected in the saucelabs tests. IE does not
support scroll restoration so IE tests were failing.
* https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/angular/angular/20061/workflows/7e16b250-f9d5-4d1b-a07d-e1cad8f366f9/jobs/788037
* https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/ca798804b244a380875abc1da5f0cff99164f539/packages/router/test/bootstrap.spec.ts#L257
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(common): Allow scrolling when browser supports scrollTo" (#38468)

Issues.Title: When using [routerLink] to construct a link that updates the primary and a named outlet, a trailing slash is added making the URL invalid
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report The issue is caused by package @angular/router ### Is this a regression? No ### Description When I construct a link that needs to update the primary and a secondary outlet using [routerLink] the final URL contains an additional '/' that causes Angular to consider it invalid. The link is constructed like this: This results in the following URL: http://localhost:8080/uw/tagent/9980/(center:gi/9980) This throws the following error: Error: Cannot match any routes. ... (please see full stack below) This is not valid because of the '/' after myid which is '9980' in my example. What I need is a way to construct the URL: http://localhost:8080/uw/tagent/9980(center:gi/9980) This link works perfectly. I believe this issue has been raised before, or something similar to it such as this: https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/21003 But the resolution what that it was not considered a bug. None of the workarounds I have found will work for me. One such workaround is to create a function that constructs the link, and a link that points to it. The function then navigates by this.router.navigateByUrl(x)... However, I do not get the benefit of the link being highlighted after it is clicked like [routerLink] provides in html. I believe this is a bug because I am using Angular to construct a link that is later says is invalid. If it is not a bug, can you please provided a workaround where I can construct a valid link using [routerLink]. Thank you for the help. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Use my code above to construct an invalid link. ## üî• Exception or Error

Issues.Title: Values emitted from the ‚Äúchanges‚Äù of QueryList are of type ‚Äúany‚Äù
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package
This feature request is for `@angular/core`.

### Description
`QueryList<T>` emits changes as `Observable<any>` instead of `Observable<QueryList<T>>`.

https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/25f79ba73e19bcf7c0925283a2dfdf2d9186eb49/packages/core/src/linker/query_list.ts#L48

### Describe the solution you'd like
```
public readonly changes: Observable<QueryList<T>> = new EventEmitter();
```

### Describe alternatives you've considered
Manual casting.

Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report

### Affected Package
The issue is caused by package @angular/forms


### Is this a regression?
Happens in previous versions too


### Description
When creating a composite form control using CVA and AsyncValidator interfaces i cant seem to propagate the errors correctly.
I have a form inside the custom form component with an async validator. When i am trying to propagate the errors to the outer form through the AsyncValidator's validate function it doesn't seem to work for all cases.
If i am writing something in the inner input - everything is working fine.
On the other hand, if i try to setValue from outside - the validation won't work. It seems as if the validation process happens on the parent before it happens on the child thus not catching the error to come.
The only way i could somehow make it work is by using NgZone's onStable observable... but then change detection doesn't work.
Is there anyway to achieve it? Am i doing something wrong? Is it a bug in how the validators are handled?


## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction
https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-ivy-h5ipor

10.0.1

Issues.Title: fix(core): remove closing body tag from inert DOM builder
Issues.Body:
Fix a bug in the HTML sanitizer where an unclosed iframe tag would
result in an escaped closing body tag as the output:

```
_sanitizeHtml(document, '<iframe>') => '</body>'
```

This closing body tag comes from the DOMParserHelper where the HTML to be
sanitized is wrapped with surrounding body tags. When an opening iframe
tag is parsed by DOMParser, which DOMParserHelper uses, everything up
until its matching closing tag is consumed as a text node. In the above
example this includes the appended closing body tag.

By removing the explicit closing body tag from the DOMParserHelper and
relying on the body tag being closed implicitly at the end, the above
example is sanitized as expected:

```
_sanitizeHtml(document, '<iframe>') => ''
```

Issues.Title: Dependency injection not working in JIT due to unrecognized delegate constructors in downleveled ES5 output
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report

@angular/core

### Is this a regression?

Somewhat (given that we implemented ES5 downleveling as part of `ng_package` and `ng-packagr` v10)

### Description

In the Angular Package Format, we always shipped UMD bundles and previously even ES5 module output.
With V10, we removed the ES5 module output but kept the UMD ES5 output.

For this, we were able to remove our second TypeScript transpilation. Instead we started only
building ES2015 output and then downleveled it to ES5 UMD for the NPM packages. This worked
as expected but unveiled an issue in the `@angular/core` reflection capabilities.

In JIT mode, Angular determines constructor parameters (for DI) using the `ReflectionCapabilities`. The
reflection capabilities basically read runtime metadata of classes to determine the DI parameters. Such
metadata can be either stored in static class properties like `ctorParameters` or within TypeScript's `design:params`.

If Angular comes across a class that does not have any parameter metadata, it tries to detect if the
given class is actually delegating to an inherited class. It does this naively in JIT by checking if the
stringified class (function in ES5) matches a certain pattern. e.g.

```js
function MatTable() {
  var _this = _super.apply(this, arguments) || this;
```

These patterns are reluctant to changes of the class output. If a class is not recognized properly, the
DI parameters will be assumed empty and the class is **incorrectly** constructed without arguments.

This actually happened as part of v10 now. Since we downlevel ES2015 to ES5 (instead of previously
compiling sources directly to ES5), the class output changed slightly so that Angular no longer detects
it. e.g.

```js
var _this = _super.apply(this, __spread(arguments)) || this;
```

This happens because the ES2015 output will receive an auto-generated constructor if the class
defines class properties. This constructor is then already containing an explicit `super` call.

```js
export class MatTable extends CdkTable {
    constructor() {
        super(...arguments);
        this.disabled = true;
    }
}
```


If we then downlevel this file to ES5 with `--downlevelIteration`, TypeScript adjusts the `super` call so that
the spread operator is no longer used (not supported in ES5). The resulting super call is different to the
super call that would have been emitted if we would directly transpile to ES5. Ultimately, Angular no
longer detects such classes as having an delegate constructor -> and DI breaks.

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction

https://stackblitz.com/angular/ggbbllnexbk?file=src%2Fapp%2Ftable-basic-example.ts

## üî• Exception or Error

Errors vary; usually it's an error about accessing a property of `undefined`. Where `undefined`
is supposed to be an injected token (like `ElementRef` or `NgZone`)

```
TypeError: Cannot read property 'nativeElement' of undefined
```

## Additional notes:

* This also surfaces in ng-packagr v10.
* This might also affect ngcc. cc. @JoostK for more concrete details here.

## Potential solutions

1. Changing the reflection capabilities and ngcc to handle the other class output
2. Not using downleveling but directly transpiling sources to ES5.
3. Disabling the `--downlevelIteration` flag when downleveling.

FYI: There were attempts in the past to fix this: https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/22642. it looks
like the issue didn't surface anymore at some point because we switched from downleveling (which we
did in the past at some point) to transpiling sources directly to ES5.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Dependency injection not working in JIT due to unrecognized delegate constructors in downleveled ES5 output" (#38453)

Issues.Title: Consider moving rxjs to patch version specification to allow significant deduplication in node_modules
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature request

- [x] new
- [ ] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc

### Description

When creating a new Angular app, the dependency spec for `rxjs` in the app's `package.json` is not exact (`~6.5.4` for `9.1.12` at this time). However, the dependency spec for `rxjs` for some Angular dependencies is exact (`6.5.4`) for at least:

  * `@angular-devkit/architect`
  * `@angular-devkit/build-webpack`
  * `@angular-devkit/core`
  * `@angular-devkit/schematics`
  * `@ngtools/webpack`
  * `@schematics/update`

This results in a situation where, due to NPM's conservation de-duplication, many copies of `rxjs` are installed into the `node_modules`. This is illustrated below:
 
```
$ ng --version
...
Angular CLI: 9.1.12
Node: 14.8.0
OS: darwin x64
...
$ ng new --routing false --style css new-app
...
‚úî Packages installed successfully.
...
$ pushd new-app
...
$ npm ls rxjs
new-app@0.0.0 ...
‚îú‚îÄ‚î¨ @angular-devkit/build-angular@0.901.12
‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚î¨ @angular-devkit/architect@0.901.12
‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ rxjs@6.5.4 
‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚î¨ @angular-devkit/build-webpack@0.901.12
‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ rxjs@6.5.4 
‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚î¨ @angular-devkit/core@9.1.12
‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ rxjs@6.5.4 
‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚î¨ @ngtools/webpack@9.1.12
‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ rxjs@6.5.4 
‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ rxjs@6.5.4 
‚îú‚îÄ‚î¨ @angular/cli@9.1.12
‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚î¨ @angular-devkit/schematics@9.1.12
‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ rxjs@6.5.4 
‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚î¨ @schematics/update@0.901.12
‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ rxjs@6.5.4 
‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚î¨ inquirer@7.1.0
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ rxjs@6.5.5  deduped
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ rxjs@6.5.5
$ find node_modules -name rxjs -type d | xargs du -sh
 17M	node_modules/@angular-devkit/core/node_modules/rxjs
 17M	node_modules/@angular-devkit/build-angular/node_modules/rxjs
 17M	node_modules/@angular-devkit/architect/node_modules/rxjs
 17M	node_modules/@angular-devkit/build-webpack/node_modules/rxjs
 17M	node_modules/@angular-devkit/schematics/node_modules/rxjs
 17M	node_modules/@schematics/update/node_modules/rxjs
 17M	node_modules/@ngtools/webpack/node_modules/rxjs
 17M	node_modules/rxjs
...
```

### Describe the solution you'd like

Change the `rxjs` dependency spec from `6.x.y` to `~6.x.y` in:

* https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/master/packages/angular_devkit/architect/package.json
* https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/master/packages/angular_devkit/build_webpack/package.json
* https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/master/packages/angular_devkit/core/package.json
* https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/master/packages/angular_devkit/schematics/package.json
* https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/master/packages/ngtools/webpack/package.json
* https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/master/packages/schematics/update/package.json

etc

### Describe alternatives you've considered

Changing the dependency spec in the apps's`package.json` to an exact version (eg `6.5.4` in for `9.1.12`) allows the deduplication, but has the downside of not allowing `rxjs` to be upgraded with bugfixes etc:

```
$ npm ls rxjs
new-app@0.0.0 ...
‚îú‚îÄ‚î¨ @angular-devkit/build-angular@0.901.12
‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚î¨ @angular-devkit/architect@0.901.12
‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ rxjs@6.5.4  deduped
‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚î¨ @angular-devkit/build-webpack@0.901.12
‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ rxjs@6.5.4  deduped
‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚î¨ @angular-devkit/core@9.1.12
‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ rxjs@6.5.4  deduped
‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚î¨ @ngtools/webpack@9.1.12
‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ rxjs@6.5.4  deduped
‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ rxjs@6.5.4  deduped
‚îú‚îÄ‚î¨ @angular/cli@9.1.12
‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚î¨ @angular-devkit/schematics@9.1.12
‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ rxjs@6.5.4  deduped
‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚î¨ @schematics/update@0.901.12
‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ rxjs@6.5.4  deduped
‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚î¨ inquirer@7.1.0
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ rxjs@6.5.4  deduped
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ rxjs@6.5.4
$ find node_modules -name rxjs -type d | xargs du -sh
 17M	node_modules/rxjs
...
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Consider moving rxjs to patch version specification to allow significant deduplication in node_modules" (#18536)

### Is this a regression?

<!-- Did this behavior use to work in the previous version? -->

### Description

It appears the migration did not update a path in ```src/tsconfig.app.json```. After fixing that, there is another error with ```tsconfig.json``` which extends a non-existent configuration, and the compiler options from base are missing. After fixing that, the build succeeds. I reproduced with a new application generated with version 10.0.1.

Issues.Title: fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): don't warn on transitive CommonJS dependencies in AOT mode
Issues.Body:
At the moment in AOT mode if a CommonJS dependency has transitive CommonJS dependency we are issue warning for both.

With this change we align the behaviour with JIT mode, where we issue warnings only for direct CommonJS dependencies or ES dependencies which have CommonJS dependencies.

Closes #18526

Kudos to @ms-dosx86 for investigating this ü•≥
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): don't warn on transitive CommonJS dependencies in AOT mode" (#18528)

# üêû bug report

### Affected Package

Not too sure what package it is covered by in this ecosystem.

### Description

So I structure my apps like `src/app/pages/page.module` and `src/app/core/models/test.model.ts` and usually, using an import in a module like `import {thing} from 'src/app/core/models/test.model` works fine, however when lazy loading that module in `app-routing.module.ts`, and commenting out the route that loads the import code, VS Code Insiders, or typescript, whichever, cannot pick up on that import for some reason.

I haven't had this before, however I also haven't commented out routes from my projects before today so it may or may not be present in older versions.

Everything still builds fine, and `ng serve` works too, which leads me to think that it's either a IDE thing, or a typescript thing. 

File structure:
```
src
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ app
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ core
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ models
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ       ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ test.model.ts
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ pages
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ test
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ       ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ test.component.css
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ       ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ test.component.html
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ       ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ test.component.ts
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ       ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ test.module.ts
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ app-routing.module.ts
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ app.component.css
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ app.component.html
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ app.component.ts
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ app.module.ts
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ assets
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ .gitkeep
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ environments
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ environment.prod.ts
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ environment.ts
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ favicon.ico
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ index.html
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ main.ts
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ polyfills.ts
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ styles.css
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ test.ts
```

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction
https://github.com/napei/ng-test-linting

Code on the `master` branch works as expected, and code on the `broken` branch is, by name, broken.

Also, here is a short demo, in case nobody can repro. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RXTsaZA6Y88

Changing the import to `import { TestInterface } from '../../core/models/test.model';` works in both cases, however if using `src/app` works at all it should probably work both ways, all the time.


## üåç  Your Environment

**Angular Version:**

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8946502/90252787-74360200-de83-11ea-8b95-8218914f82ea.png)


**Anything else relevant?**

I don't know if this is a language service issue, but this is the log for the language service extension version `0.1000.7`
https://pastebin.com/raw/TqsF7u07

I am currently using `VS Code - Insiders 1.49`

Issues.Title: feat(@schematics/angular): always extract css on newly generated applications
Issues.Body:
`extractCss` will be deprecated in version 11 and the new behaviour will be to always extract css because for HMR to work we no longer the need to disable CSS extraction.

With this change we move new applications to the new behaviour.

Issues.Title: fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): fix detecting commonjs deps in parent deps
Issues.Body:
For now if we import a library (that exported as a CommonJS module) as an ES6 module, but has CommonJS imports, we get a warning for the library and also for its deps.

In my case I was using `camel-case`, but got two warnings for `camel-case` and `no-case` that is used by `camel-case` internally. Here is a minimal repro https://github.com/ms-dosx86/commonjs-warnings-repro
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): fix detecting commonjs deps in parent deps" (#18518)

### [`v2.25.0`](https://togithub.com/rollup/rollup/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#​2250)

_2020-08-14_

##### Features

-   Add `--failAfterWarnings` CLI flag that will complete builds with warnings but return an error at the end ([#​3712](https://togithub.com/rollup/rollup/issues/3712))

##### Pull Requests

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/rollup/rollup/compare/v2.23.1...v2.24.0)

_2020-08-13_

##### Features

-   Allow defining interop per dependency via a function ([#​3710](https://togithub.com/rollup/rollup/issues/3710))
-   Support interop "auto" as a more compatible version of "true" ([#​3710](https://togithub.com/rollup/rollup/issues/3710))
-   Support interop "default" and "esModule" to avoid unnecessary interop helpers ([#​3710](https://togithub.com/rollup/rollup/issues/3710))
-   Support interop "defaultOnly" for simplified helpers and Node ESM interop compatible output ([#​3710](https://togithub.com/rollup/rollup/issues/3710))
-   Respect interop option for external dynamic imports ([#​3710](https://togithub.com/rollup/rollup/issues/3710))
-   Support live-bindings for external default imports in non-ES formats unless "externalLiveBindings" is "false" ([#​3710](https://togithub.com/rollup/rollup/issues/3710))
-   Use shared default interop helpers for AMD, UMD and IIFE formats ([#​3710](https://togithub.com/rollup/rollup/issues/3710))
-   Avoid unnecessarily deconflicted module variables in non-ES formats ([#​3710](https://togithub.com/rollup/rollup/issues/3710))
-   Freeze generated interop namespace objects ([#​3710](https://togithub.com/rollup/rollup/issues/3710))
-   Always mark interop helpers as pure ([#​3710](https://togithub.com/rollup/rollup/issues/3710))
-   Avoid default export interop if there is already an interop namespace object ([#​3710](https://togithub.com/rollup/rollup/issues/3710))
-   Sort all `require` statements to the top in CommonJS output for easier back-transpilation to ES modules by other tools ([#​3710](https://togithub.com/rollup/rollup/issues/3710))

##### Bug Fixes

-   Handle accessing `super` in static class fields ([#​3720](https://togithub.com/rollup/rollup/issues/3720))
-   Deconflict the names of helper variables introduced for interop ([#​3710](https://togithub.com/rollup/rollup/issues/3710))
-   Generate proper namespace objects for static namespace imports in non-ES formats ([#​3710](https://togithub.com/rollup/rollup/issues/3710))
-   Do not add unused interop helpers when using the renderDynamicImport hook ([#​3710](https://togithub.com/rollup/rollup/issues/3710))

##### Pull Requests

-   [#​3720](https://togithub.com/rollup/rollup/pull/3720): Handle super in static class fields ([@​lukastaegert](https://togithub.com/lukastaegert))

Issues.Title: Web worker syntax error in IE11
Issues.Body:
I have a web worker in **Angular 9** that is throwing a `Syntax error` in IE11. Looking at the debugger, it is on this line:
`const worker = new Worker('src/workers/attachment.worker', { type: 'module' });`

Removing `{ type: 'module' }` moves past the error, but of course returns 404.
`new Worker() will only be bundled if passed options that include { type: 'module' }.`

How do I make Angular web workers work in IE? Is this a bug, or am I doing it wrong?

(Note: my web workers are working in Chrome and Firefox)

Issues.Title: ng update --all updates other packages
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [x] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? No ### Description The expected behavior of ng update --all doesn't match documentation. I use ng update all when updating angular core and material (4 ng 'packages' typically) but this command updates all my other libraries and ignores semvar rules. It's been the default behavior for as long as I can remember. I would like to use ng update to just update all my angular/schematic packages and ignore other npm packages, or to at least respect semvar restrictions when updating other packages. The docs imply this might be the case "--all=true|false - Whether to update all packages in package.json. Default: false" ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Take any angular project that isn't on the latest minor version (i.e. ng 10.0.8 vs 10.0.9), ensure there is at least 1 other package that has npm rules set to not update major (i.e. karma-jasmine: ~3.3.1) ng update --all will update karma-jasmine package to 4.0.0, using --all=false doesn't seem to have any effect either. ## üåç Your Environment

Issues.Title: bug(youtube-player): When loading youtube player inside a Tab the iframe refreshes
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Use StackBlitz to reproduce your issue: https://components-issue-xxet19.stackblitz.io

Steps to reproduce:
1. Include a youtube player in tab component
2. switch tabs and you'll see the iframe re-loads.
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

What behavior were you expecting to see?

The iframes should not reload, just because we are switching tabs

#### Actual Behavior

What behavior did you actually see?

The iframes are reloading

#### Environment

- Angular: 10
- CDK/Material: 10
- Browser(s): All
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): All
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(youtube-player): When loading youtube player inside a Tab the iframe refreshes" (#20329)

Issues.Title: About MatProgressSpinnerDefaultOptions#_forceAnimations definition
Issues.Body:
#### Expected Behavior
I'd expect a clarification whether it's really public or a private.

1. If it's public, I'd recommend to get rid of the "_".
2. If it's private, I'd recommend to mark it with `@docs-private` because right now it appears on [docs](https://material.angular.io/components/progress-spinner/api#MatProgressSpinnerDefaultOptions).

#### Actual Behavior
`MatProgressSpinnerDefaultOptions` have a private (?) property: https://github.com/angular/components/blob/a6f1a33998af82db7fa960a66fc851058bf60c98/src/material/progress-spinner/progress-spinner.ts#L60

I was about to use it to disable animation globally, but the `_` confused me, as this symbol tends to mark as a private API and, therefore, can change at any time, without respecting the depreciation period.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "About MatProgressSpinnerDefaultOptions#_forceAnimations definition" (#20327)

Issues.Title: help(matBadge): Getting error Type 'number' is not assignable to type 'string' with strictTemplates flag
Issues.Body:
#### What are you trying to do?
I am using the `matBadge` directive and I need to pass some default value to the matBadge(for example 0, 7, etc). But as I enabled the strictTemplates flag in my `tsconfig.json`, I am getting an error
`Type 'number' is not assignable to type 'string'`
since the `@Input matBadge`  is expecting a [string](https://github.com/angular/components/blob/master/src/material/badge/badge.ts#L91).

I can fix it by doing something like:-
`@Input() badgeValue = '7';`
and then pass it to `matBadge` directive, but I feel like this is annoying.

Can anyone help me with this?

#### Environment
- Angular: 9.0.2
- Material: 9.2.0
- Browser(s): Chrome

Issues.Title: feat(autocomplete): support variable option height
Issues.Body:
Historically `mat-select` and `mat-autocomplete` have behaved very similarly, because they were written around the same time and they share some logic by depending on `mat-option`. `mat-select` has to know all the option heights ahead of time so that it can position its panel correctly over the trigger. The limitation made its way into `mat-autocomplete`, even though there's no reason for it to be there.

While implementing the MDC-based autocomplete, I refactored some code that makes it easier to support variable-height options so these changes enable the functionality for the non-MDC autocomplete too.

Fixes #18030.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(autocomplete): support variable option height" (#20324)

Issues.Title: help(Overlay): position strategy when origin is clipped?
Issues.Body:
#### What are you trying to do?

I am trying to set a position strategy that works when origin element is clipped. Is there any way to do this without writing a custom position strategy?

#### What troubleshooting steps have you tried?

I tried all the strategies available through CDK Api but without success.

#### Reproduction

https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-rplbez

Basically, i have to 2 connected positions defined. First that will center the overlay below origin element and another one that will center the overlay above origin element. For example, if element is on the top of the page, overlay would go out of viewport and then second position will be used (below origin element). That works fine. But if origin element is clipped (as in stackblitz example) then overlay will be positioned using first position (above origin element).

Steps to reproduce:
1. Click on a blue square
2. Opened popover is over red header
  
#### Environment

- Angular: 10.0.9
- CDK/Material: 10.1.3
- Browser(s): Chrome 84.0
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): MacOS 10.15.3

Issues.Title: bug(Datepicker): Date range selection only - dateChange event doesn't emit unless Ivy is enabled
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Using Date range selection, if enableIvy is set to false in tsconfig.base.json then (dateChange) event will never fire, whereas the single date pickers will still emit this event.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Set ```"enableIvy": false``` in ```tsconfig.base.json```
2. Setup ```(dateChange)="onDateChange()"``` event on an input within ```<mat-date-range-input>```.
3. Note how this method within in the component is never hit.
4. Set ```"enableIvy": true``` in ```tsconfig.base.json``` and repeat steps above, now dateChange will work.
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

(dateChange) should trigger with Ivy disabled.

#### Actual Behavior

(dateChange) does not trigger with Ivy disabled.

#### Environment

- Angular: 10.0.9
- CDK/Material: 10.1.3
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows 10
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(Datepicker): Date range selection only - dateChange event doesn't emit unless Ivy is enabled" (#20305)

Issues.Title: help(CdkTable): Cdk Table is not instantiated with production build
Issues.Body:
When running `ng serve` everything works 

Just upgraded to angular 10 and got everything working, finally got to running a prod build and not of my DataTables are loading. Using `ng build --prod &&  npx angular-http-server --path ./dist -p 3001`. It seems like the CdkTable is not instantiated because the DataSource.connect function is never called.

I have a component library that has also been upgraded to angular 10 and works, the component library has a DataTable component that use `<cdk-table>` like so: (this has been working with prior versions)

```
 <cdk-table
          [dataSource]="dataSource"
          [trackBy]="trackByFn"
          [class.expandable]="expandable"
          [class.empty]="dataSource?.currentlyEmpty && state.userFiltered"
          [hidden]="dataSource?.totallyEmpty && !state.userFiltered"
          #table
        >
```

I added `@ViewChild('table') tableRef: CdkTable<T>;` when I console.log this i get:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1056055/90169699-f7b0ff80-dd6c-11ea-8039-49686bb4141e.png)

#### Environment
